channel.title: [PHP/MySQL] Methods of cutting/listing
channel.description:
So I'm working on a big project, hoping to earn myself some money with an obvious idea that has not been done with a specific category.
Now I'm a beginner at PHP and SQL and I'm as far as the basics at the moment.
My question is what is the most efficient way of storing a manually-listed selection into a database? I will give an example: ->Niggerbitch is typing down each and every single possession he owns in a list. In a text box, he writes down:
>Mike's Bike Vlad's Bike Cory's Bike Tyresha's Bike Muhammad's Bike<
A total of 5 possessions, each separated by a space down.
When Niggerbitch clicks the trigger, these are stored into the database, and then shown on the main panel, each one listed down followed by a bullet before each entry, ex:
•Mike's Bike •Vlad's Bike ...and so on.
How would you all fit this into one table field, (labelled 'possessions') and then convey them into a DIV, separated correctly?
What I think is to have them go into the database like "Mike's Bike;Vlad's Bike;Cory's Bike..." and each ; is str_replaced with a bullet and a \n.
The problem is I don't know (i can't understand guides for shit, someone help me) how to work with string replacing, and idk a way to insert those entries into the database in this method.
help plz

item.title: [PHP/MySQL] Methods of cutting/listing
item.dc:creator: @Ollie Ollie
item.description:
@Ollie wrote:

employer_id would be a primary key in the employer table but in a job table (for example) where employee’s are assigned to jobs employee_id would be a foreign key.

a primary key can be a foreign key too, thats called a one to one relationship but i try avoid them as they are not really needed as one to one relationships can be put into one table.

Read full topic

item.title: [PHP/MySQL] Methods of cutting/listing
item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:
@Mopman wrote:

mutex_:

Foreign key is a relationship between two tables; for example if you have a table with Employees and another table with Employers, you’d relate them by Company.

That’s not a very good description imo. You seem to be describing some kind of relationship that requires an intermediary (company) like has many :through in rails… but foreign keys are much simpler than that.

In your example, employee having a column employer_id to show which employer it belongs to, employer_id is a foreign key.

Read full topic

item.description:

stackoverflow.com

Primary Key versus Unique Constraint?

database, database-design
answered by Mark Brackett on 04:55PM - 01 Oct 08

Read full topic

item.title: [PHP/MySQL] Methods of cutting/listing
item.dc:creator: @z z
item.description:
@z wrote:

[quote=“DEFET, post:6, topic:410225”]any way to elaborate on the difference of primary/foreign/unique key?

i read shit on google and it does not show any examples, just talk. i rely on examples to learn things.

so you want me to create a new table named possessions, and each separate line inserts a new field with the item name in it? seems a lot more simpler than my idea, and worked nicely

@lawl_temp:
let me try to attempt this on my server real quick.[/quote]Primary key uniquely identifies rows (an ID, for example).

Unique key on a specific column means that column must be unique in every data row. You can’t have two values the same in that column. For example, an e-mail column. You can’t have the same e-mail for two users.

Foreign key is a relationship between two tables; for example if you have a table with Employees and another table with Employers, you’d relate them by Company.

Read full topic

item.title: [PHP/MySQL] Methods of cutting/listing
item.dc:creator: @lawl lawl
item.description:
@lawl wrote:

slavemaster:

Possessions should have a primary key as some sort of auto-incrementing ID and also an index as their owner’s user ID.

foreign key the owners id

anyway if you care at all about your user you’ll make an interface that lets you keep adding new items instead of just typing them into a text box

Read full topic

item.title: [PHP/MySQL] Methods of cutting/listing
item.dc:creator: @z z
item.description:
@z wrote:

FYI, nobody will do the reading for you. Here is a start.

[code]<?php
if(isset($_POST[‘input’]) && strpos($_POST[‘input’],"\n"))
{
$items = explode("\n",$input);
foreach($items as $item)
{
$item = htmlentities($item);
$sql = “INSERT INTO possessions (possession) VALUES (’$item’);”;
mysql_query($sql);
}
}
?>

[/code]

Read full topic

item.title: [PHP/MySQL] Methods of cutting/listing
item.dc:creator: @Budda Budda
item.description:
@Budda wrote:

Hahahahahaha.

Read up on Databases, and accessing them…but mostly database design, cause I have a good feeling that you know fuck all about databases + SQL

e.g. Instead of putting all the possessions into one field, you should have a possessions table, with each field in that being a separate item.

Read full topic
